summarization: we spent two separate nights at this hotel as part of our tour of india. the hotel is heavily used by and geared to tour groups, but there are a lot of arrivals and departures in the night and early morning, which may be disturbing to individual travellers. we would not hesitate to return for an overnight stay.

the hotel and rooms (although large) are characterless. service in the restaurant was OK, as was the food. when we arrived at midnight we were unable to get a beer - bar closed and no beers in mini-bar!
road works when i was there so getting to and from was a problem but was over come. taxi ride away from nightlife in delhi is an excellent stopover if visiting Delhi. good pool and excellent food.

this hotel would qualify as a high end 3 star hotel. it's an older resort style hotel but has few amenities. the grounds are manicured and well kept and the pool was clean. if you are just looking for descent cardio equipment it should get the job done. The breakfast served was minimal but all you can eat. Overall our stay was pleasant and would consider staying again.

this is one of the nicer hotels in Delhi and is conveniently located near both the domestic and international airport. hotel charges astronomical rates for its taxi service, so this certainly wouldn't suit the budget traveller.

we stayed on our first and last nights in india, it was our airport hotel. the restaurant was quite convenient, when the buffet is on, that's what you have to have - otherwise you choose from a menu. we also enjoyed the breakfast, with plenty of choice available, and the gift shop was small but pleasant (although they did try to sell us an elephant with its tusks missing).
food,services room ambience everthing was really great. Not very close to town but good place to stay. good location to visit.
the hotel is overpriced and its directorial policy - greedy. the rates changed when we were there, but they still charged us for the higher rate quoted in our e-mails.

we (husband, wife and teenage daughter) stayed at the Ashok Country Resort for one night only. Probably the poorest value for money place we spent in during our two week holiday in Rajasthan, Agra and Delhi. given the relatively high rates, I'd rate the resort as below average at best.

the Ashok is a transit hotel used by holiday companies to accommodate travellers for one or two nights on their way in and out of india. the first floor rooms in the hotel are rather dark and dismal and in need of some refurbishment.

the homepage of the Ashok Country Resort promises more than the hotel can provide. the garden is very nice, but it isn't calm because of traffic outside. it looks so nice from outside and in the lobby. but the room was not very clean and the beds were clammy. i was really disappointed.

the hotel seemed adequate for our hectic schedule as there was very little leisure time. grounds and pool seem nice but didn't have the time to explore that much. the food was reasonable for both dinner and breakfast.
i was supposed to stay for 4 nights but ran after 3 couldn't take it anymore. the worst rooms he has ever stayed in are motels with better service and rooms.

we were arriving late from Bangkok with my girlfriend and on our way to Agra, so we thought we'll stay near by the airports. we had to look for the hotel driver in the line of all the other hotels driver at the exit gate for 30 minutes before the guy showed up, then it complained to us about the delay in addition of being plain rude...the room was horrible, look 20 years old, not even a proper mattress on the bed, the beds and towels were 10 years older...we ordered some room service at 0
great hotel, close to Delhi international airport, is ideal for a 1 night stay before an early flight. the main restaurant opened at 7pm, but it is not for light meals.
we found this Hotel good as part of the tour but for independant travellers would probably be too far out of town. evening meal was ok for one or two nights and breakfast was very good.

we booked our stay for only one night in this hotel. we reserved a pick up service and upon arrival at the airport, we didn't see any one so the driver was upset and complaint and try to have an argument with us.
this hotel was a very welcome rest away from the hustle and bustle prior to leaving Delhi. the well manicured gardens and the relaxed bar and restaurant were just what we needed.

we arrived at this hotel on a kuoni golden triangle tour. if you drink wine the price is astronomical.staff friendly but they tried to charge us for our transfer to the airport which was sorted through kuni!!!!but you expect these tryu ons in india.food was good.i loved the omletts at breakfast.the rooms were very well decorated. overall this is an amazing hotel with truly lovely gardens and the lovelly swimming pool.

we booked this hotel as it was near the airport and was supposedly a very high standard. the manager greeted us an said 'any problems come and see me" and charged the full amount of our stay on our credit card - very suspicious. there was no hot water in the room asked at reception and asked to wait an it would be fixed. an hour later the water was cold. I eventually lost my temper and called another hotel (the Raddison to stay there).
the hotel is on the outskirts of Delhi and is a great escape from the city. the pool was nice and the grounds were really well kept. we were generally pleased with this hotel.
the hotel was conveniently situated for the airport but a longish taxi ride from downtown Dehli. the pool was pleasant and the staff were fine.

the hotel was conveniently situated for the airport but a longish taxi ride from downtown Dehli. the rooms were pleasantly decorated, clean and comfortable. The pool was lovely and very nice to sit beside with an cold beer. we phoned for radio cab to take us to the Sound and Light at the Red Fort (well worth seeing)

a transit hotel in the suburbs can be hired for 1/2 day/night. the hotel is located right next to the busy road - 10 mins from the airport.Must request an 'quiet' room as this hotel's location is not bad for the locals and their need to blast their horn at every living thing they pass regardless of the time of night!

this hotel is the worst hotel I have ever stayed at. I had booked the room several months prior to the stay and had email confirmation of the exact cost. the bathroom had a strong smell of urine and the air conditioner made the smell even worse.

the pollution in the area near the hotel/airport is horrendous and it seems a losing battle at this hotel. the air quality really bothered me here and not elsewhere.the room was the bare essentials. it reminded me of Eastern Europe inthe 80s and the gift shop was not enticing. The hotel is not easily accessible to sights.

the owner of the hotel was in attendance and keen to speak to all the guests and made sure everything was up to standard. it had a lovely pool area and nice restaurant (it was upstairs and no lift but that was the only problem for one of our party who is less mobile)

the staff put heaters in the rooms, the bathroom was a little old but clean all the same. the only problem was that they only put the hot water on at certain times of the day so its either cold or tepid showers overall.

the hotel chosen, I suspect, because of its proximity to the airport. when we arrived, Delhi was very smoggy, but that atmosphere pervaded it. i couldn't help worrying about the athletes coming here for the Commonwealth Games, hope they clean up their air quality before then!

the hotel taxi was parked 10 minutes walk away and with paying the carpark it took 40 minutes before we arrived. my flight was delayed, ended up staying for 3 hours.a good advise for whn you tay shortly, ask or you can nagociate the price.

we arrived around ten in the evening and they had the correct rooms (twin beds, non-smoking) ready. they let us have tea and toast before we left which was nice of them. we used the half day rate that day and it was great to come back from the long trip to Agra and shower and change before our flight to the us.

on a recent trip to india we stayed at the Ashok Country Resort for our final night before flying home to the uk. the hotel was by far the worst place to stay in and the service from the reception was nothing short of rude and prices for drinks and food were 5 star hotel prices. Earlier in our trip in Delhi we were able to hire an air conditioned taxi for the price this hotel charged for an airport transfer.
we used the Ashok for a first night in india and were very satisfied. the hotel was comfortable and clean and the pool was good - we got over any jet lag. it seems to be good value for Delhi.

the hotel provides a well signed, adequate and reliable transfer for IGI Airport to hotel, transfer time 15 mins. the rooms are big, clean and fairly comfortable. Feeding arrangements are good, but beware hordes of French groups on tour, and Kazak aircrews on layover.

privately owned and operated, this full service hotel is located between city and airport and caters to Indian businessmen and European tour groups. Upon arrival one can not help but be impressed by the beautiful marble floor and stair case of the two story lobby with its massive crystal chandelier. the owner's son sits on a desk in the lobby and is very accommodating, as is the staff.

hotel rates go in delhi, we paid £75.00 per room per night, and that included b/fast and airport pickup and drop. hotel is in a quiet location near the airport,rooms are big and comfortable,staff are polite and nvery helpful,food is not bad either.

we stayed here two nights in late march 2007. the hotel is fenced off and so it feels insulated from the hubbub and traffic. they let us take the salwar tops back to our room to try them on. bottled water to take with us on our next leg (8-hour drive to Nainital)

the Reception staff were aloof and not very welcoming esp. as we were there on the first night of our tour. the room was fine with clean crisp bedding and a descent size, though the view was of 'a wall & the window didn't quiet fit the frame'
stayed here on 1st and 7th day of the Kuoni Taj Tour. it's mainly clean, everything worked in the bedroom, although we had a very noisy fridge.

when we arrived in Dehli we went straight to the hotel. the room was cold and the bed damp, we had to request an additional heater in our room! breakfast the following morning was okay. staff were helpful and polite. this is an average tourist hotel. good value for money.

staff were pleasant and helpful, but they were booked solid. the rooms were clean and quiet, bathroom clean, adequate and good varied buffet breakfast. nice gardens, and the pool looked nice, though it was too cool to try it in December.

we decided to stay in the Ashok after checking lots of reviews. the dew-smell smell outside was damp, but the rooms cannot be opened and are only airconditioned, and the smell was outside damp. there was a huge cloud over Delhi and no fresh air outside the garden. The people at the reception very polite and gave us our call to the airline free.

we stayed at the Ashok Country Resort for the first and last night of our Golden Triangle tour and again for a final night after our extention to Shimla. the room was OK the second stay was not so nice but had better view over the garden. it also had information about the Beauty Shop..we walked to the local village.... took 20 minutes not 5 as reception told us...BIG mistake.

this was the most disappointing hotel we stayed in in India. the room was not cleaned properly, smelt a bit damp, no information in room about hotel facilities, poor outlook onto courtyard and no hairdryer in the rooms. only redeeming features were friendly staff, nice grounds and near the airport, suggest try elsewhere.

room was lovely, with a large screen plasma! very clean. far too expensive for what it was (I paid £76) the grounds are very nice but the buffet restuarant is terrible. good for the airport and the atmosphere feels very relaxed - the chicken I had was hardly cooked and they didn't really seem to care.

the hotel staff were all very friendly and they even agreed to hold one of our bags for us while we did our golden triangle tour. the only downside is the distance to the city - it is about 45-60 minutes and costs about $25 by taxi. it may not be the best place to stay for your entire journey if you plan to go in and out of Dehli everyday.

the hotel is comfortable near the both airports, nice when you arrive in the middle of the night and need sleep. the rooms have a good size; on the bathrooms you see the complex is older, but we have no complaints about it.
stayed here for one night only as it's convenient fot the airport and we were flying home next day. helpful staff, comfortable room and good food.
a transit airport hotel would lower the room price by about one third. they also tried to overcharge us for the rooms until we showed them their email including the price.

stayed here twice for one night in different rooms during a tour with Kuoni. overall the hotel is quite acceptable for short stay, and it's only approx 20 minutes from the airport. the rooms were fairly well appointed, the AC worked well, though the beds were very firm (we later found out that this is normal in Indian hotels).
the gym is ok but opens late at 8am only. the hotel was close to the airport and price point is good. however the level of services is not up to mark. there is no in room internet access.

the surcharge on long distance calls as charged by them could not be justified on any account. disappointing, to say the least. i was disappointed with what I got. the food was tasteless, the refrigerator in the room not working, room service willing, but incapable due to lack of experience.

this is one of the worst hotels we stayed at during our time in India. the check-in and restaurant staff were rude, the restaurant was very poor and the carpets were stained - the price was expensive compared to other hotels. value for money was also poor since it was not even cheap. for a Gov. run hotel, it needs to get its act together.

the hotel is owned by GOI, and so they get preferential rates. it was of the caliber of a nice Marriott -- clean, spacious (I'd stayed at the Taj Palace in Delhi 10 days earlier -- that was about as glitzy luxurious as I've ever been) service was professional but not obsequious, not overly solicitous.

the state of the hotel is miserable, the only thing that has been restored is the entrance lobby. there is a problem with staff and front desk staff in particular - they are not interested at all to give any service to their guests. their only interest seems to be to get tipped! next time I definitively will look for another place to stay in Delhi.
I stayed in Ashok for 2 nights during a conference. the hotel has been booked by the organisers of the conference so I had no choice.
the location is quite good almost midway between the city center and the airport. the food was average and we preferred eating outside in the private restaurants situated within the building.

great expansive property in one of the best areas in delhi. the hotel is trying to modernize post privaitization and addition of Fbar and the host of events it hosts is propelling it forward.Price is normally around 8k INR which makes it the cheapest in Delhi.Always full of foreigners, Indian bureaucrats and Indian airlines crew, this is a nice value for money hotel.

jet Airways provided us one night stay at this hotel. hotel was given by airline - but we didn't find hotel equal to 5 star hotel standards.Rooms were smelly,A/C was not effective,No Courtesy by staff,Breakfast was cold,Dinner wasn not good in taste.

as an invited participant of an' international Stakeholders' consultation,I was accommodated in 'The Ashok',Chanakyapuri,New Delhi. aristocratic name in the diplomatic enclave of the capital city raised our expectations to perhaps somewhat unreasonable limits.
ashoka hotel is one of the grandest hotels built by the govrnment. the hotel has exceptional facilties - the gym and swimming pool is very good.

this is a very lousy place with nothing great about it and comes with very high tariff rates. everything is very costly and rooms are not well maintained, the only exception is the its Restaurant Frontier which serves good food.

i stayed at the Ashok this past week and was relieved that it was not as horrible as the other reviews indicate. my room did not seem dirty, and housekeeping came daily, so maybe that helped. roaches are hard to eradicate in that part of the world. it is a third world country, after all...i think the problem is that they are charging first world prices.

the staff were poor, the views awful and generally just disappointing. our deluxe room had a comfortable bed and that was about it. the six restaurants in the hotel only two were open and one was just vile.the other was average but top prices.Our 3 1/2 night stay cost £700 - do not stay here.

the reception's staff was informed that the rate is the same. the staff at business-center tried to be of help and while services are really expensive, none of the 11 mails I had send arrived arrived... trying...

we wanted to spend time in some good hotel so we could remember the stay as well as the places of stay. we had heard a lot about Hotel Ashok, how magnificient it is and how marvelous the view from the hotel top looks.

the Ashok is a government owned hotel and does not have the massive private investment of the other in the diplomatic enclave. I was greeted by staff who were friendly and helpful throughout my stay, and the decor is good, the place is clean and clean. everywhere I go I am saluted or bowed to. the decorations are good enough, nothing special and Paprika Chicken is awful, don't try the chinese restaurant, we ordered 3 plates of food and some rice and each dish

my husband and I went there for a medical convention. the next morning we went to the hotel room late...Surprise! room was smelled up with tobacco! thanks heaven we brought our rubber slippers! you can't walk inside without it!

hotel staff were a little creepy. our hallway smelled very bad (especially in the mornings) luckily, most of the smell remained in our room and didn't come into the room - it was just better in comparison.
the staff was the rudest I've encountered anywhere, the room was dirty and the location was far from anything, and it was of course overpriced. I highly recommend against staying here.
the windows didn't fit properly so you had the noise and the smell of the traffic. we would have booked into a B&B in the bazaar if we had wished to experience such an establishment in my life.

the Ashoka Hotel is one of the most reasonably priced 5-star accommodation available as it is still government owned. the acommodation is good and the service even better. will definitely use this hotel again.

i found that my hair dryer would not work, my television, not the desk light, and some electrical sockets. when my message light showed, I discovered that the message key didn't work - the first person I asked to help me on this never came back to me in the room on it. the food (which tasted quite good, or at least the indian style food) was very expensive, but we waited 15/20 mins for some water to be brought to us, the use of wireless access cost $25 a

the hotel staff gave me the key to someone else's room and then acted like I'd done something sneaky to get it. if you haven't already grown sick of hearing "madam, take a glance, no need to buy, just look, and get your fill on your way to the elevators.

Hayes & Jarvis 'upgraded' us to the Ashok from the Oberoi Maidens for the first 3 nights of our India tour. we read the reviews and hoped it would not be as bad as reported, but unfortunately it was. our rooms were dirty, especially the bathrooms which looked as thougth they had not been cleaned properly for years.

the Ashok at USD400 a night for an ordinary hotel room, ordinary tired property with ordinary to below average service. the room is clean, the bed comfortable and the water hot but for USD 400 you want 'a little bang for your buck'

overrpiced - London prices for poor quality rooms and miserable service. the lowest point was when waiter in the lobby lounge wiped the tea cups with his finger, and later washed our cups behind the desk with water from a mineral water bottle, from which he was also drinking.

the hotel issued the same room to another guest after midnight. the room is qutie recently renovated and the bathroom has no bathtub so the floor is wet after shower. there is not enough space to place toiletries too. I could hear TV noises from other rooms and staff can be loud when they go around their duties along the corridor.

the hotel has a good potential and facilities are worth five stars. for me, it was the last time that I stayed there. if the management can cope with the housekeeping issues it will certainly get better ratings.
my husband and we stayed at the Ashok Hotel last weekend. the receptionist upgraded us to the executive floor at regular rates - the room was clean with a view of the pool and plasma tv.

we had a terrible shock at the Ashoka Hotel. when we arrived in our room the porter followed us in the room withouth an invite we were shocked! they refused to take credit card payments and would only accept cash!

stayed at the hotel Ashok, 50B Chanakyapuri, as part of a group tour in Delhi. it is in new Delhi south of the government area, with no neighborhoodto walk to, and no nearby subway. we found the service to be fine, but it definitely does not deserve its apparent 5 stars or justify the price(apparently $200+).

the service is about as bad as it gets. hotel restaurants are pretty poor as well - I had to send back under cooked chicken, and the fish got its revenge during the night :-(Was probably a great hotel 30 years ago but now rooms are shabby and run down.

two nights at the hotel and the first night was terrible. the telephone looked like it hadn't been wiped down in 25 years, seriously no joke. I demanded a room switch so the second night I stayed in the newly renovated ones (the older, crappier ones will be renovated on soon)
an average 3 star hotel trying to be 5 star. the public areas are ok but the rooms are old, tired and dated. but others were paying $200 a night - sheer robbery.
this was the worst supposedly 5* hotel we have ever stayed in. the staff were extremely rude, food was awful and the rooms were old and grubby.
the hotel is ok if you pay not more than 80 EUR a night for the room. staff were friendly, room service quick, and the adjunct restaurants seemed to be alright, but everything there is just 'alright'

hotel rooms were stinky. it was worst hotel I ever stayed in. I paid 180 $ (INR 8000) for 1 Night.Hotel reception was ok but Rooms are dead.I needed a hotel near US embassy so I unluckily chose this one.

this hotel classifies itself as a 5 star DELUXE hotel and it probably was, 50 years ago. the exterior looks charming because of the architecture, very colonial but Indian at the same time. however, the inside is quite strange.

the hotel is ridiculously noisy and stinks of must and exterminator's chemicals. the service ranged from indifferent to rude, except for the coffee shop staff and a smattering of housekeepers, it was simply outrageous. it has some great restaurants, an excellent spa, and bags of potential. but the government has got to stop pretending this is an five-star hotel.

the government run hotel could be a splendid example of traditional Indian grandeur, its website claims. despite the lack of rooms in the city, I was forced to stay at The Ashok for my last business trip.

the rooms are old and run down and staff are generally not very helpful. the only good things are the staff in the restaurant and the breakfast buffet. if you are staying in india, spend a bit more money and stay somewhere else.
the Ashok is a tired, grimy, grubby hotel. the rooms are dirty and dated, the service is surly and unatentive.
I originally was excited to be able to stay here after so many years. between the lousy food, the crappy rooms and the creepy guys (security & maids) in the hallways - this is one hotel to avoid.

we found grey towels and bed linen at 5* hotel. all over the hotel were signs of government ownership - too much of staff, equipment out of order, etc. I expect for that price you can get much better deal.

I was staying at the Ashok hotel between the 11th and 16th of may 2006 for business reasons. During my stay I found the rooms to be unclean and unsafe! whilst moving the hairdryer I received an electric shock. I reported this to the duty manager and asked to speak with the general manager.
the balcony was very dirty, paint peeling off wood work and no balcony furniture. the windows were cracked, putty coming away and dangerous to open.the staff were rude, dismissive and unhelpful.

Location: In Between Airport, Sites and Central CityService: Above Average Price: High for location, but worth the ratingRoom: Within the rated rating. within the ratings, location: in between airport, sites and central cityservice: above average price: below average value: 0 compared to the average location location. a good location - close to location and close close proximity to airports, site & central City.

hotel Ashok is a big hotel in the diplomatic district of new delhi. it has many restaurants and shops and the lobby is Ok, but the hotel was nothing near being five star. "Cleanliness' had no definition in that hotel : my bed sheet was dirty and stained, the minibar refrigirator didn't work and it was empty. the toilette mirror was rusty.

we spent our afternoon trying to get cleaner rooms rather than sight seeing. we finally got some rooms that were a little cleaner than the ones we first saw and ended up staying at the Ashok for one night in february. the management was neither friendly nor helpful. try to avoid staying here at all cost.

we stayed in a suite on floor 5, this was well sized and we had 2 single beds put in the spacious living room. the room was good (uk 4 star std) the bathroom was not as good but adequate and the hotel overall is quite dated but in Delhi is probably quite modern.
stay at hotels such as Oberoi which are in a similar price range but deliver first-class amenities and services on all fronts.

the scale is so big that if the hotel is not full it is almost depressing eating in a 300 person restaurant. the new bar Steel is the best option this place had it was freshly done with good staff that tried and an excellent relaxed scene. It was the only real haven there where I did not dislike my stay.

receptionists personel asked my wife how long we are going to stay like they were afraid that we dont have enough money to pay. the restaurants had a good service except the chinese restaurant which they warm the food for 2nd time before the serve it.

the staff were very grumpy looking and mean and behaved more like they did not really want to be there. the only saving grace was the performance of the musicians in the restaurant, Needless to say. i left the next day for another hotel.

external appearance is great. the employees dress like professionals. but service is really poor. I stayed in one room. there was heavy construction noise very nearby. also there were block in bathroom sewage. Reported the trouble. they changed me to another room, but again not so good bath room and toilet (for the amount they charge).

the location of this hotel sucks, the area is unlit at night...desserted...so for a first time traveller it made me uneasy...it was basically in the middle developing hotels...construction surrounds it...I think they are trying to build an community of resorts. the room was small but nice, modern. we ordered room service, it wasnt bad.

we were told we would be staying in a four star hotel in Old Delhi. however it transpired that we instead were booked into this hotel which is 25k from Delhi in another town altogether, Faridabad, an unattractive industrial area. the room was the worst we stayed in throughout our two week stay in India.
the atrium hotel was active almost around the clock at the time. the service ranged from being, in the best case, just very awkward, to being extremely intrusive. in general it was always bad.

we stayed at the Atrium for three nights in April. all staff were helpful and friendly. the entrance is grand, the communal areas are well decorated, and the rooms are comfortable. power can be erratic at times, but this is to be expected in Delhi.you will need transport if staying at this hotel, as it is a little out of town.
the avalon comes out of nowhere. the hotel is ideally located in the area it is situated in and you are thinking the worst!
the approach road to Avalon appears unfriendly and dilapidated. inside the courtyard the rooms are trendy and have a mini kitchenette - the long french windows lead into nothing... err!

the Avalon was a pleasure to walk into - bright and spacious reception with modern decor. very clean and pleasant check in procedure. staff were friendly and attentive when required.Downside is the location.

if you travel outside of this hotel you may need to pay a tax to get entry back into the district (your taxi will not pay this fee) it is also far from the sights and city center so be prepared to spend around 700Rs for 40m or 4 hours. we probably wouldn't go back because of location and proximity to anything in Dehli worth seeing.

I stayed in one of the Residence suits which was lovely. the staff were delightful, really friendly and helpful.the spa was very nice and all facilities were included in the room priceInternet was super fast but expensive at 500RS for 2 hoursBreakfast was also delicious. it took just 30 minutes to get from the hotel to the airport for my homebound flight so it was really convenient as an overnight stop.

the residence room is nice as it's similar to service apartment. the staffs are ok but not really communicate among themself first. i was plan to go to lotus temple and reception guy call to chek that it is open on that day but when we went their it was close.
Sutese were very nice. Very modern and well equipped. Terrible view from window of high canvas fence installed. the restaurant was unlicenced and there was no bar in the hotel.
this is a very nice, clean well serviced hotel. the gym is great, on staff massages available, and the internet is really good, although expensive.a great find.
we travelled along rutted filthy streets in the rain so our first impression of India was not so good. the driver pulled into a lane way and said here we are, we couldn't see an hotel!
breakfast was served early for us as we were on an early train to Agra. a clean, modern and reasonably quiet breakfast stayed well.

my girlfriend and I stayed at this hotel for one night at the end of our recent holiday. the hotel is ultra modern and totally lacking in any of the character and charm we experienced during our stay at all the other wonderful heritage hotels and palaces throughout our trip. when you enter it, you feel like you are walking onto the set of some science fiction movie.
new property had just opened this month. rooms are spacious and well suited for a medium term stay. Microwave, couch and small frig in each room.

this hotel was away from the centre of Delhi so make time to travel in and out. rooms are spacious, modern. service was prompt and the food was good.Pool area is a bit run down and not very well attended.

we stayed at the Claremont hotel because we were looking for a reasonably priced, clean comfortable hotel near the Delhi airport. distance-wise, the hotel is not that far, however it took us 40 minutes to drive to the airport at 7:15am on Monday morning, so we had planned for at least that amount of time. our room had 1 King and 1 twin bed that was brought in so it really only slept 3 comfortably.
Hall & Poolside Lawn are perfectly maintain for private function. good stay and dining arrangement with family for couple of days.
hotel is made with class & surrounded with greenary area. staff was Courteous and well groomed. I really recommend this Hotel.
specialy indian & pasta's ; open pool with huge lawn for exercise or move around. over all nice hotel for stay with friend and famliy.

cox and Kings travel agency used it as an 'airport hotel" although it's 25 minute drive from the airport. the rooms are clean and decent, but the water was only lukewarm when I took a shower at 3:00am.

castle and King TourServices booked into the property on the tail end of an otherwise wonderful trip to Rajastan India. we encounted a non flushing toilet and had to use the lobby facilities all evening. noassistance to repair was available.

pakage was great as the hotel was, we were on triple occupancy. we enjoyed the weekend with all recreational stuff & evening with great wine..........food is equaly good but expensive enough......andamp clams to be 4star, its fair enough to  be...............and it's a 4 star hotel with 4 stars - it is the best hotel in the world!...we have stayed this holiday holiday on weekend!! i'm happy to stay here again again
the rooms are very spacious and well maintained. the hotel restaurant is very good and serves Indian and continental food. a good place for business meeting and conferences.

the conference hall was huge and the staff was cooperative. they did make all arrangements as per our requirements. the food is ok, not great. Overall good for business travellers and tourists travelling alone or couples. May not be attractive or value for money for families.

the reception staff at check-in was probably a trainee from one of the hotel management institutes - had absolutely no clue about my reservation. the room was spacious, and relatively clean, with the TV being an old piece of junk that made strange crackling and hissing noises. luckily, I had no opportunity to sample the food, except for breakfast on the first morning.
the staff stood me out while they went to the room and checked the minibar status how much to charge me while I was in a hurry to get to airport.

i stayed in qutab hotel in march for a day. it's purely not business class hotel.building is old and very average in terms of rooms and services.cleanlyness is ok but not very good.moreover the surroundings makes it worse.there is an garbage dump near by.no gud market near par.bad locality.i would merely not recommend it.
this is not a 5 star hotel by any standard. there are true luxury hotels in Delhi. the hotel is in the middle of nowhere surrounded by nothing. it's old and tired, and so are the rooms.

this hotel claims to provide a 5 star service and facilities but falls very far short in terms of delivery. staffing attitude - patina of obsequiousness displayed by staff was not matched by the concept of service provision to the customer 'obstructive and just plain unintelligent'

rooms are spacious, some with great flatscreen tv, others with standard equipment. good beds, minibar, in room safe, okay bathroom (not much water pressure in shower). swimming pool looked good (but too cold to try, outdoor)
we stayed here for one night at the start of our tour & for 2 nights. the rooms were very clean, modern, quiet and comfortable.

stayed at the Qutab twice for a total of six nights in June 2007. internet worked fine, and 2.5 Euros per hour is not an unusual charge. you don't want to walk around in the neighborhood, except maybe into the park just next to the hotel.

the hotel was rated and regarded as one of Delhi's Delux hotels. it is not located in the downtown core of the city, but set admist absolute squalor. the property caters to mostly Indian business people and is definately not for a tourist visiting Delhi. not recommended.

hotel staff in Delhi will tell you what you want to hear about their star rating. I paid $140 per night for my stay, but demand is greater than supply for hotels, so they charge you whatever they can think of. if there are no rooms available, they are not going to bother to let you know in advance.
we stayed at the Quatab for 14 days last year and the service was exeptional. we are trying to book again for 2006 and are looking for a new book for 2006.

my family and I stayed at the Qutab on 2 separate occasions in january 2005. on leaving we did not have time to go to the post office and post our holiday postcards - about 20 of them. So we left the money for postage with staff in the reception and someone promised to post the cards.Now, 3 months later, nobody has received a postcard.
Conclave Comfort is one of the 3 hotels by the same group in the surrounding locality. ideally situated specially for people travelling towards Okhala.

the phone on the floor rings very loudly every time the hotel gets a call - annoying, it's impossible to sleep. the room is smelly, warm water tap doesn't work and is very dirty. breakfast room in Delhi is ridiculous, dishes not clean and so on!

we were booked to stay a couple of nights and we only stayed one. the heater was on but it got lost in translation along the way from heater to shower head. we are told an engineer is on his way up and assures us there will be hot water. at this point, we have now lost about 2 hours or more from our day.

corus is supposed to provide a 3 star experience to. the frugal sorts whose budget is below 4K this seems to be the best place available. if you increase your budget to 5K you choices are limited. staff is extremely courteous/professional and helpful.3. Cafe coffee day at the entrance and the general location is excellent as far as connectivity is concerned.
I stayed in the hotel for two nights & enjoyed my stay. The hotel is very centrally located, and the room had a wonderful view. I could see entire Connaught Place.

corus was the most expensive hotel we stayed at in India. the location was great, right on the center ring of Connaught Place in between Old and New Delhi. there's a great coffee shop in the front (with REAL coffee, hard to find in india).

we had three rooms for our group, two of which were dumps. one room on the top floor at the front of the building had access to a superb terrace with stunning view of Connaught Place. others have complained about all kinds of aspects, and they're true. it's kinda dirty, the breakfast was terrible and the rooms are horrid without the terrace.

stayed with family for three nights at the beginning of a 3 week holiday. the tiny rooms could have been cleaner, dirty windows gave us our first look outside. staff was friendly and helpful. fortunately most of the other hotels were of higher quality than the Corus.

"hotel's location was one of the worst I have ever stayed in. very noisy, rooms offexternal corridor backing onto dirty back streets.very basic amenities,worn sheets, bug-tablets, no hot water.No lift, had to lug bags upstairs.

myself and 3 colleagues stayed at the Corus in the end of November for a week. the hotel was booked by our Indian colleagues and it was reasonable - and much better than I had anticipated. main problems were:- No hot water for showers- My room was the only room with window- the shower flooded the bathroom when you used it- at night it wasn't noisy outside and my colleague had boiler above his room which made noise constantly- The room serivce was terrible, microwaved, luke warm

we arrived to our room around 11 pm and requested an 8 am wake-up call. either they misunderstood us or we were woken at 3 am. we got dressed and then looked at our watch so we ended up drinking tea in the room until breakfast. breakfast was outside in a patio area and was done very nice. they didn't put out an abundance of food so the hotel must have not been full but it was tasty.

the first room we were shown had no windows but they moved us to one at the back with a window off an external corridor. there were bugs that came up through the shower drain, but perhaps this is just an feature of New Delhi - the reception staff seemed either exceptionally helpful or surly, no in between.
a friend booked this hotel on tripadvisor and checked out the hotel. the pictures made it look much more promising than it really was.
there is the door bell man INSIDE THE ROOM STEALING FROM THE BAGS. the manager from the hotel asked me not to call the police, and try to 'digest it'
the best part of the hotel is its location - the inner circle of Connaught Pl. you are right in the heart of Delhi and next to the subway/metro.

first time we stayed we had a standard room, which could also be called world's smallest room. the bathroom, barely room to turn around, was fairly clean but we didn't sleep well at all as we were right by the stairs so it was really noisy. i found the smell really overpowering. they have little white balls in the sink (accord to my husband you get these in urinals)

hotels in new Delhi are notoriously overpriced, and after four nights we stumbled across the Corus Hotel in Connaught Place. we immediately booked a room for our return five weeks later. the price was Rs 5000...about US$135. The final graceful touch was after allowing us the free use of an available room in which to rest before our late night departure to the airport.
the hotel's location is very good - right in Connaught Place. the staff was friendly though the front desk was understaffed.

we stayed at 6 hotels during our stay in india and all the rest were good to pure luxury, this hotel is really a 1.5*, i couldtn give it even 2 stars. the air con was extremely noisy so we switched it off, but the humidity in the room was awful as there was no air or natural light.

if you are gonna be out of the hotel during the entire day, then there is no point to spend a lot of money to the other 5 star hotels which you need to pay between 300-500 USD per night. it's at the Inner Circle of Connaught Place, where you can find many international fast food restaurants, shopping places, post office, etc..

the hotel was totally over-priced for the quality of the experience. it cost 5000 rps, plus tax, for a double room for one night, and was based on the latest review in Lonely Planet. the staff were friendly, but unhelpful. when we had problems they couldn't fix them.

the reception area is nice & was being refurbished when we arrived. my room was in the main block and had no windows. it was very quiet. air con fan worked really well. the only problem was getting hot water. there was never any. a cold shower suited me fine. I would recommend this hotel to others.

hotels in Delhi are overcharged and we didn't want to spend so much. we booked directly with their webpage and also payed for airport pick up, since we arrived late at night. the hotel is ok, the bed is clean but the bathroom is awful! no hot water and found many big insects at the shower.
great place, good service, excellent oriental cusine at the restaurant called Bonsai. overall a very comfortable stay. keep it up!

price: excellent $90Location: Excellent - CentralService: Hospitality Redefined. New hotel, Great ServiceRooms: Small, but Reasonable – Neat, Clean and comfortable.they should show more of their room pics than passage photos on their website's'

we stayed here for 3 nights after arriving in india for a 3 week tour. the room was large but with grubby sheets,tepid water and the special bonus of blood stained towels! the breakfast which comes to room is only white sliced toast although we noticed Indian guests having cooked food in the corridor as there is no dining room.

their motto is "Hospitality Redefined'' which, after reading this personal account, is quite apt but for all the wrong reasons. the exhorbitant fee of U$155 nightly plus 1212% Delhi hotel tax fee includes phone bills charged to your room, no toilet paper, only Pepsi in the room bar and no offstreet parking.

they have started charging on the Wi-Fi use, 100 rupees per day. double room price at 900, and although the rooms are reasonably clean and quite nice, most are nothing like the photos on their web site.
they have an elevator, free luggage storage, they offer airport pick up and drop off for a minimal fee. they also offer city tour by private taxi, so you won't have to ask for more.

cottage Yes Please has friendly and helpful staff and a nice guy that says 'Namaste' to you when you come and go out the front door. the only downside is that they no longer have free wifi -- it costs 100 rupees per day now.

if you arrive at reception, you are asked to show your passport as they cannot wiat 15 minutes for you to get in the room, unload and refresh. then, they demand you pay in advance - even though you're out of local currency and you have stacks of dollars to display them 'if I have recovered from my journey'

stayed here for 3 nights+ OK staff+ Good location for travelers+ Room service + Good rooms- no hot water in the room- driver we organized to the airport through them kept falling asleep at the wheel (not technically their fault) 3/5/5.

the hotel is one street over from the main Bazaar road in an area called Pahar Ganj. it's teeming with activity and there are endless shops where you can get inexpensive handicrafts, clothes, colorful tapestries, henna body painting, etc.

cottage Yes Please is on a side street off the main Pahar Ganj bazaar. it's the filthiest neighborhood I've ever stayed in, with mud and livestock in the streets. the hotel owns two pretty good restaurants across the street -- Malhotra and Dosa Please.

a good hotel considering the price and location. good location in dingy pahar Ganj/Main bazaar, but really close to the metro station so you don' t really have to walk through the city if you want to.
it was our first night in Delhi and we decided to stay in the Pahar Ganj area. the a/c room was ok and clean but very hot before the noise woke us up at the airport around midnight.

the hotel itself was reasonable and clean, especially in comparison to the majority of places in new delhi. the AC did not work for half of the time, and there was hot water for about 5 minutes in total. we were billed for 3 nights, when we had only spent two nights at hotel, on the spurious grounds that we arrived before 12 noon on our first day of our stay. after losing our tempers the manager reduced the fee to half a day, but in any case our last day in india was dampened by

room 406 is located at Phar Ganj, very convinience to go to Agra. the hotel is very clean, staffs are so nice. all kinds of facilities are available, ex, train booking, taxi, internet, money change. restaurant on roof top is started, when I was there, it was under construction.
the rooms are ok, a reasonable size with some natural light. ours had fridge and tv, but there were stains down the walls which I'm sure could have been removed with good clean.

the greeting room/ entrance is fairly nice. the rooms are dirty and beds uncomfortable. Bathrooms old and dirty with no hot water - even when asked specifically if we wanted hot ice we didn't get any!Didnt eat breakfast there...didn’t dare.

Rooms #409 & #410 are the only renovated rooms in this hotel. Located on the same floor as the restaurant. Nice breakfast but horrible dinners. I wouldn't suggest ordering anything, walk around the corner and get a veggie burger at McDonalds and the Indian sweet shop - Bikanervala.

the bus tour departs from the Crest Inn. it was the off season so it seemed relatively professional and structured for tourists. the driver was curt and didn't understand my questions and attempted to leave without me after breakfast. when we came to the first stop in agra, my bus was nowhere to be found. there are infinite transportation-for-hire options in India so I was able to make it home again using alternate transportation.

the Crest Inn hotel is one of the cleanest places you will find in Delhi. it was the only place where bedsheets and towels did not need to be changed out the minute we entered the room. the hotel restaurant is not much for food, so be prepared to head out for all your meals.

the bathrooms have bath tubs which leak and toilets do not flush properly. breakfast is served in an untidy small room and is often not prepared preoperly. the staff were very pleasant however and tried to make our stay comfortable. please avoid this hotel.

the last day we came to settle the problem but they just told us that it was a mistake & didn't want to pay us back. we were forced to look for an other hotel (first night in India...) in the late night... we found it thanks to the taxi driver.

the hotel was booked by a travel agent and the 2 star rating was lower than we had talked about. we wanted to minimize our expenses, especially since we believed that we would also be using room service in the u.s.

it's web site makes it sound like the Ritz! what a shock when I arrived. Reception staff not very friendly, workmen on the stairs painting and repairing the lift. the dining room was just as bad. Don't go near the place!

Travel agent said was one of the 'better' hotels in Karol Bagh! I would avoid and go to the hotel Swati down the road!Room: very noisy from street noise, plumbing etcShower: Poorly maintainedService: OKRestuarant: Dull, dimly light, ok food/menuBreakfast: Standard fayrefast. hotel was a good hotel!
it was an excellent hotel and the food was also good. There were Swiming pool and spa facility were excellent. we got hair hair cut from Silvi. the room was awesome.
good service, nice and clean."Too much attention sometimes from service staff.Nice with gym inside the hotel.nice.

the room service staff were rude and unhelpful on every occasion Buffet restaurant is just indian food and no variety.surrounding area verry dirty dirty. the rooms staff are friendly and eager to please but if you don't keep the privacy button on they knock in the hope of tips!

the Crowne Plaza Delhi is 5 Star Deluxe Hotel located in the heart of New Delhivery very good arragment. the hotel is a 5 star hotel.... the... the crownel is the best hotel in this..... the 5star Deluxe hotel was located at the top of the new Delhii......the best place to stay!
cozy interiors make you comfortable in the rooms. all the necessary amenities are at available, great reastaurant and nice food makes everyone happy.

the breakfast was so bad it defies description vegetarian omellete with bacon in it, uncooked eggs served as an amellette, hairs on the food. therooms were ok but small, but stay if you are desperate foor your room, otherwise avoid at all costs at any costs.

the hotel is nice, the room is comforable and clean and serviced well. the reception staff were rude and unhelpful on every occasion I needed to speak wih them. if you don't keep the privacy button on they will knock frequently in hopes of tips!

it was our first time in India and at a Crowne Plaza hotel. our room overlooked the pool and entrance to the hotel. on arrival everything during registration was completed while we were able to eat the cold drink. the room was quite large and there were always bottles of water on our return every day. The atrium bar is lovely and quiet but like everywhere in india expensive. we did not have the buffet although it looked very good.

you can rent a driver and car and tour around Delhi, which is amazing. it was my birthday when we booked in and as you have to give your passport they saw the date and arrived up to my room with the birthday cake, present and flowers.
the word Hospitality should make sure that the staff "Does not Humiliate and Insult'' its guests.Learn the Basics before even thinking of running a hotel.
the service was way above standard for india, about average by Canadian standards. the rooms were the cleanest of anywhere we stayed in India - rare it seems in Delhi.

the hotel was booked by local colleagues for its location to the office, and sort-of-good facilities. the staff are well-meaning and try hard, but are not polished, I'm sure. a better training would help as you can tell they are trying to please.

they have customised services for japanese guests like TV channels and breakfast. food is not too great for the kind of money they charge, better to eat out in the shopping arcade outside the hotel. they also have services like tv channels, fft stts & a personalised service for their guests. cld have been better, they offer bespoke services to their customers.

the staff at the Crowne Plaza Hotel New Delhi is outstanding. I had price issues with our first night stay. the hospital that booked us waited to long to get the lower price rooms. i was forced into the higher price and didn' t know until check out. we paid and went on to a hospital where I was admitted. one of the managers came to the hotel to speak with us. she made our trip! service slow in main restaurant and food not to our liking, the Japanese restaurant was awesome! the ja japan restaurant
the property is large and well-appointed if not particularly attractive to look at fomr the exterior. the food is good and room service very efficient.

i had an opportunity to visit new delhi recently and to stay at crowne plaza. check in was really easy, with cooperative staff. the room was very good and exactly as promised on the hotel website. in short, it was worth it.
Surya has large and spacious rooms.the food is excellent. the front office staff is very efficient and not well groomed. location is good too, considering the size of delhi.

five star hotelgood for official partieslocated in posh south delhicentral location in southgood servicegood food. 5 star hotels in the south of the afl hotel - five stars hotel good for the official party parties. the hotel is located at the 5star hotel hotel in central location. st ls hotel with fas : 5 stars for hotels with five-star hotels..
floor 3/ regular twin bed room!nice breakfast, great room service... bathroom fitted with latest amenities...defintely a recommend for any frequent travellers!
the shopping arcade is reasonably priced and shopkeepers open to negotiation so one can get a steal. the chinese is absolutely delicious.
the location is so-so, and the surrounding area less accomodating to intrepid guests than other parts of the city.

Intercontinental is consistently superior on quality. Crowne Plaza was a tad more expensive (for which read extortionate; this is Delhi, after all) than the admirable nehru Place - but some way behind the quality. the walls appear to have been painted by the same five year old responsible for the grouting around the shower!
nice place, nice membership benefitsclean, all facilities, centraly located.nice bufffets and everything u think is above normal grade.

the hotel did a very poor job of organizing the leisure package that I had selected. even after talking to the resident manager, they did not address the matter. Very poor service for what the charges are.
this hotel is a good choice for you to stay for two of days. just expect an excellent room and no other services including service.

new Delhi is not the greatest place to stay in what is the wonderful country of India. it's convenient for Aggra and as a brief stop-off before going to the north - but not really great destination in its own right. if you do happen do be in New Delhi (I was for 8-days on business April 2009) then I certainly recommend the Crowne Plaza.
its an excellent hotel... Stayed there many a times on official visit... Excellent ambience, service, location. excellent location, excellent atmosphere and service.

the electrician arrived early evening and when we switched on the lights some worked, some didn't, the TV and air con did not work. by now it was getting late to eat so we again thought, only one night we will leave the aircon off.night 3- we arrived 11.00 pm.
the hotel is extremely good. rooms are lavish and beautiful. I liked the hotels rooms the most.See the room photograph below. a room photo of the rooms is shown below.

the hotel gym is small and smelly and is crowded as everyone gets there at the same time after work and your better in doing an early morning workout before you start work.food is apalling and the choice of western food is disappointing.

the shopping arcade & food courts adjacent to the hotel is the best. a great location, warm welcome and great food. this hotel, perhaps is best in Delhi for business travellors. well connected to delhi and neihghbouring states UP, Haryana etc.

Crown Plaza in Delhi is always a great pleasure to stay in. it has good restaurant, good rooms and good location. the hotel is located in the heart of the city centre and is just 5 minutes walk from the train station.

the fare has risen in the last few months, but corporates do tend to get attractive discounts especially for long stays. the hotel is one of the best that I have come across in New Delhi. it has all the modern amenities that are required for a business hotel.

the restaurant and bar were very nice, but really expensive. the breakfast buffet was really good, everything is geared towards Japanese and Western tourists. a good breakfast was excellent and the room was very comfortable.

the recent Indian currency depreciation helped- so 9,000-10,000 rp now translates to just $200 vs. over $250 6 months ago. hotel management responded to my complaint- at the manager's reception I upgraded to club room with less noise.Certain issues:1. Short power outage, happens several times a day, even in the lobby- after terror attacks, I was kind of alerted.2. Avoid connecting room- noise from neighboring room is too loud- I heard the cough next
the hotel is some distance from both the cultural centre of Delhi and the international airport (over half an hour in busy periods - from each) the surroinding area is quite filthy.
hotel rooms in india are expensive but in this hotel you receive exactly what you need after a busy day in the city (clean rooms, bathroom, comfortable bed, international TV channels, internet, etc)
food wise they have a 24 hour cafe/restaurant on the ground floor which serves Indian and Continental dishes. rustle up good plate of fries which are great sandwiched between some butter naan!

great hotel with good service overall. the rooms are well equipped but on the small side. tried out the 2 restaurants - the top Chinese restaurant was very good although quite pricey for India standards! staff generally very helpful. not much in the surrounding area except small shops and restaurants.

the room was nicer, and at the end of the hall so maybe a little bigger. we only asked for one rollaway bed, which at first was separate mattress on the floor! they let us keep our extra luggage for free and kept an arriving parcel for us.

stay here at beginning and end of tour in India booked with Jetsave. reception area lovely and pool very nice with beds in shade. unfortunately several swimming lessons for local children held in the pool made it crowded and noisy at evening time when you wanted to use it. Room good with complimentary bottles of water and tea and coffee making facilities All our meals were paid but drinks pricy here.

the hotel is located nearby shopping areas, banks, resturants local markets ect. it is fit for any kind of traveller,for business,tourist,or family vaccations, if you should travel to India in the future, will choose this hotel for my stay.

the hotel is out of the way from the airport and main tourist areas. staff refused to accept that I was told it was complimentary, and demanded to pay it. i was with a co-worker, who also heard it is complimentary. now, I dont even really care about the money, work pays for it, but the principle of it bothers me.

the main open areas are airy and bright, nicely fitted out and the bar area below reception lacks atmosphere it’s a good place to meet. breakfast buffet was very good, especially if you like Massala Dosa for breakfast like I do, there were omlettes and fruit.

my business colleagues booked three nights for me in the Crowne Plaza during a recent business trip to our nearby India headquarters. the public spaces are spacious and flashy, and are intended to impress, mainly due to its convenient location near my colleagues' work location.
the hotel has a problem with the air conditioning: at restaurants and in the lobby it is very cold. it takes ages till you get served (tea arrives after the breakfast is done)

we stayed here on the first night of kuoni taj tour. arrived early morning (7am) and they managed to get us in a room for half eight, which we weren't expecting. we went to the local shops to go to an ATM. it's obviously an expected part of india to encounter fairly stark poverty, but it was still an eye opener. staff were very friendly and hotel was very modern and clean.

we stayed here twice during a recent tour of india. both times it was welcome place to stay in an hectic city.spacious lobby, spacious room,extremely clean and well kept.Staff was helpful, breakfast was good.
stayed at Crowne Plaza with group of 5 girls for whom this was part of India 'experience' girls arranged day trip to Taj Mahal with meals and guides.

I have stayed in this hotel 3 times over the past 4 years, travelling on business; the last time was December 2006. I stay because of it's proximity to my business. the rooms are clean and spacious and really what you'd expect from a 4 star hotel.

the service in the hotel was below average and at times was totally ignored by staff at hotel's reception. hotel lacks atmosphere and beware the rooms on the 1st floor, often the very rooms offered by some travel websites.
the double bedroom was large enough to move without problems, big bed with excellent mattress, clean sheets, room equipped with desk+chair, sideboard, armchair with table, flat-screen tv.

the pool was clean, with an impressive lobby but the room was smallish, had old decor, and had a shakey door that needed to be repaired. the post cards that i gave to the bell desk (with money) never arrived in Australia. would not return to this hotel.

stayed at the Crowne Plaza for 6 weeks while on a business trip. hotel was clean and staff friendly. Overall an excellent hotel and will be even better once renovation works are all completed, unfortunately this did mean loud noise/banging sometimes but staff always helpful and apologetic.

the hotel itself isn't as luxurious as the Taj Palace in Delhi in terms of service, food, and comfort, but its still pretty excellent. the location of this hotel is also excellent, it is within walking distance of some great resturants, both Indian and Non-Indian, Ego Thai which is nearby was great and some of the best thai food I have had from around the world.

I was upgraded to the Premiere Club floor but was unable to partake of the amenities and perks. the hotel policy is that upgrades to Club Floors are not welcome or able to use the club floor facilities. they gave me a very expensive auyervedic massage in the spa.
the hotel is not closed to the center, but you can hire a 3 wheeled car for 100 rupeehs per hour (don't pay more!). transfer by local taxi to international airport takes about 45min.
the hotel was in my opinion excellent. the restaurants were good and breakfast was excellent. I stayed at this hotel as part of a tour.
the hotel is located on the outskirts of the centre of Delhi, but as it is such a vast metropolis I would not make location an issue.

we booked for 7 nights but could only handle 3- we managed to get in to the Hyatt hotel - new and clean. the hotel is near the middle of Delhi and the Crown Plaza is miles away for anythingBook the grand or the hyatto / the Grand, I wish we did from start.
the hotel was OK, but quite far from the airport if you're just staying overnite as we were. when we arrived, they said they had 1 room for 2 people, and were sold out.

the reception was huge and dazzling.there were plenty of lifts available. the breakfast was buffet style and very good. they catered easily for my gluten free diet.the staff were courteous and friendly.

the staff at this hotel is outstanding. i had price issues with our first night stay. the hospital that booked us waited to long to get the lower price rooms. I was forced into the higher price and didn’t know until check out. my husband was furious. we paid and went on to a hospital where we was admitted. one of the managers came to the hotel to personally speak with us and clear up the issue. our room was lovely and the service was slow and food not to our liking. The Japanese restaurant was awesome!

this hotel in Delhi is an upmarket property to stay with. we all were booked for two nights and our stay was an experience worth sharing about. our Check in was done with soft drinks and warm welcome by the Reception lady, room was on the renovated floor with paintings in the corridor reflecting Indian art(impressive).

my name is Wilson Garry stayed between 3rd Sep 06 and 07th Sep 06. I was highly worried about my trip to New Delhi. check in was prompt and welcoming, was given a room on the 2nd floor which was fresh and contemporary. Room had features like LCD screen TV, Cubicle bath,bedside console etc.

the Crowne Plaza in New Delhi was probably a great hotel ten years ago. the hotel was under renovation, and supposedly, some floors are completed - but it is showing its age. i did not see those floors. The lobby needs help. my room needed help, but the electrical outlets were iffy, the fixtures were cracked, fading, or the marble surfaces were showing much of wear. I need to have an electrical outlet next to the bed for some medical equipment that I use when I sleep, so it's
we arrived early on the morning after an overnight flight and were very pleased to be given a room at 7.30am. the room was newly refurbushed with flat screen TV and well equipped.

stayed at the Crowne Plaza for 2 nights, had an excellent room on the 7th floor. it had been recently refurbished with modern amenities including a large plasma TV. the Chinese Restaurant was excellent (but not cheap), we used the executive lounge for breakfast and snacks and the food was very good.
most of the rooms need refurbishing and the bar area has got to be the most inhospitable place in India! forget any intimate surroundings, this bar is in the atrium with 30 m high ceilings.

the hotel is located right next to the new Delhi railway station(NDLS) the metro station is again at a walking distance in fact closer than NDSL. the negatives i mentioned shouldn't be an deciding factor according to me given the security issues which the country faces.

the hotel is very close to the new Delhi Rly station. there is a metro entry just out side the train station, and the metro is just outside the station. if compared Room rent vs Cleanlilness, it will rank-1 in India. for Train Traveller, even better.
very warm and cozy rooms, plush interiors, nice service and tasty food. good connectivity for business and tour planner available in the hotel. excellent value for money.

for $40 you get clean rooms with satelite TV, AC, wireless (must pay but only $5 for 24 hours) and clean bathrooms. we also stayed at a few 5 star hotels which were (as expected) better but then again cost us $300... found Ginger to be the best bargain around.
the hotel's location is just yards from the unimaginable filth and detritus and all-round excremental disgrace that is the new Delhi Sewerage Station, I mean - New Delhi Railway Station.

we booked ginger Delhi for 2 days and left hotel with 2 hours of checking-in. hotel staff did not even check if room was clean before handing over the room - they cleaned it and only cleaned what we showed. after a second glance there were bunch of hairs on the other side of the bed that the cleaner royally ignored.the walls had shoe prints. but at least I expected housekeeping to clean those marks from the wall. the quilt was almost black from one side and had couple of yellow spots all over.

taxi driver 'phoned' ginger hotel and was advised they'd over-booked. he apologised profusely and explained how the sister hotel was so much better than it was a scam, so we were immediately able to book in!
ginger hotels is a chain of hotels in India, mainly set up for business travellers. the Delhi hotel is right behind new delhi train station so centrally located for seeing the city.
a good restaurant, business station and travel desk within the lodge are within walking distance. railway station is 5 min walk away, and is close to the san francisco airport.

ginger new delhi can't be ur second choice... it was so calm, peaceful and clean that at time i felt to leave the place never. so cheap and nearby to the station it is an amazing place to live in in. it's a beautiful place for the u - if you want cleanliness, you're the best! 'it' was clean, so clean and so peaceful that when it wasn'' he stayed in it and was incredibly clean.

this hotel has small rooms for 1 person which cost about half of a standard room, so perfect when traveling solo. if getting there by taxi, be sure to tell the driver it's by the Ajmeri Gate of the train station or they'll have hard time finding it - and book at least one week ahead of time. it books up, mostly by locals.

the restaurant is open 24hours with good food although the staff are very rude and unanattentive. downside is that there are no shops around the hotel and you need to get to them (Connaught Place 5mins) which are available just outside a hotel.

this is an excellent choice and great value for the price. the room and bathroom were clean, A/C was great, flat screen TV with cable, hot water (though much better in morning than night), very cheap phone calls, internet in the lobby and very helpful staff. restaurant is ok. if you check their website, it will show it fully booked for months to come.
the ginger hotel was nothing great but it's only one stop by Metro (entrance very close to the hotel) to Connaught Circus where there are plenty eating places. Would definitely stay there.

the hotel is basic but clean enough. Room has complimentary water (2 bottles a day), hot water pot, TV. there are 2 computers available in the lobby for Rs 110 for 1 hr. the staff was friendly and means to be helpful. one just has to give them time.
ginger booked our 3 night stay in new Delhi for 1000 rupees. the location is amazing - bang next to the railway station.
TATA have opened this hotel in the railway station complex and not inside/ near airport. the cost of the food is little higher which tATA need to relook at..
CP is the best place to dine.6. 24hrs restaurant7. Water dispenser on every floor8. Very courteous staff including room service staff.
real value for money hotel. an ac room at rs 999 is an excellent value-for money. san london hotel is the best value hotel in the utt - if it is worth it..
I was travelling to Delhi from Mumbai and this hotel came as a surprise choice after me completing the train ticket on irctc.co.inI was directed to www.railtourismindia.com.

we were on the way to Kerala and stayed here in a twin room. we strongly recommend this hotel to all the visiting couples and families. one of the best thing is the easy access of railway station. you can even see your train standing at platform no. 10, 11 and 12 while having west side window opening rooms.

this hotel is just steps from the new Delhi train station. it has clean rooms, comfortable beds and decent bathrooms at very reasonable prices. the area around the station does look a bit intimidating but I never felt in danger, even late at night.
the rooms are clean, the staffs are very polite, No disturbance, Overall I would say you get an ambeince of a five star at the cost of 3 star hotel.
great hotel with everything you need - mini fridge, flat panel TV. 4 beds in family room, free water bottles, separate shower,toilet,washbasin etc.

this hotel is good but is not ar per the desired standard. I have also visited the Bangalore Ginger hotel but this one is in Delhi not so good. also there is no room service at all. so this is also a problem.
the 3-star Raunak Hotel is the best value for money. the service was good,the food was splendid and the staff were very helpful and understanding.I really enjoyed my stay there..

stayed here on 2 separate occasions during March and rate the hotel very highly. location is walking distance from new Delhi train station which is ideal if you want to catch a train at 6 in the morning. rooms are clean, modern looking, have good air conditioning system, flat screen TV's, good hot showers and comfortable beds.
the ginger has all the atmosphere of a businessman's hotel, but the rooms are clean and neat and staff is responsive to requests for assistance.
ginger hotel (the erstwhile Rail Yatri Niwas) is very nice hotel. the room rates are also resonabel at around 1200 Rs.

the hotel is a budget hotel, so don't expect any frills. you'll find omelette and toast, and you can get an auto-rickshaw for 5-10 minutes and go to Connaught Place to eat something. if you like Indian food you’re going to enjoy yourself.
113 rupies per hour, wi-fi everywhere, pharmacy, corner shop and a tourist desk. ginger hotel everywhere we'll go in India!
the ginger is cheap, clean and comfortable. we tried a 4 bed family room and the 2 bed twins, both fine and have better bathrooms.

hotel Ginger is a quality accomodation and 'a steal' for the low prices. the rooms are very tiny but well done up - the corridors are maze but blame it on the old building and construction. currently accessibility from the city is big problem because of the construction of Metro, but once that ends this hotel will be hot favourite for people travelling by the railways.

the ginger has all the atmosphere of a businessman's hotel, but the rooms are clean and neat and staff is responsive to requests for assistance. the hotel is on the back side and across the tracks from New Delhi Station - and the constant activity makes the area relatively safe. you get courtesy bottles of water every day.

the hotel is magnificent. it was so peaceful, no disturbance at all from anyone - it's not hard to drag ourselves away from it to go anywhere. its ambience is so quiet, there is nothing to disturb at any from any person. i would say this is probably the best hotel in the price range of Rs 1000/- per day.

the hotel is just a stone's throw from the railway station. it was an unbelievable facility for the price at this location, with tea kettle and tea packs in the room. if you are planning to stay there, please make sure that you book your room well in advance.
the area around the hotel isn't too safe, quiet or clean. it is just near the new Delhi station so u can imagine all that mess around and how is it at night.
Id give it 5/5/5. it is the best value for money option for all kind of travellers.It gives it a 5-star rating.
the hotel is very neat and clean and for the price one cannot get a better deal. they also have restaurant, laundry service, LCD TVs in each room, etc.

the family room contains 4 beds. with AC, pretty spacious room with LCD TV for 1000 is too good. also proximity the new Delhi railway station is BIG plus. now don't have to go for the infamous Pahadganj hotels.
the hotel is located on the North East side of the metro and New Delhi Railway Station. the staff were very attentive and the restaurant was adequate.

this was one of my worst experiences!!! i finished a whole day work in delhi & had to return to this hotel in the night. the arrangement for my stay was made by my office in Mumbai. I tired calling the hotel serveral times during the day to inform them that I have arrived, only in vain as no one answered the phone all throght the morning.

the service here is very slow though the food is nice. pre-paid auto-rickshaws are available at the new Delhi railway station which is a 3 minute walk away and the metro station is 3 minutes away as well.
good hotel to stay if you are travelling on business or work for a day or two. the facilities are minimal but adequate. 'good hotel' for business travellers.
we took a family room for just INR 1000. the hotel is just oppositte the new Delhi Railway station within the station premises.
ginger hotel is truly a business hotel for business traveler like me. they best advantage with ginger Delhi is its location advantage.the facilities provided by the hotel are above average.
ginger mgt serviced tata as the most trustable brand of world. it was a gud exp.. i can't even imagine service like the one he got.
food is available but is in cafeteria like place Had a few issues with them messing up over the bedsheets but was otherwise ok.

a Basic Service Hotel, right next to New Delhi Railway Station. we wanted 'a Hotel Near Railway station' as we were transitting next day to goa by flight - stayed in the same hotel as ginger in Haridwar and Goa. the hotel was very clean and clean due to Metro work on in nearby vicinity, the railway station Parcel office etc making it very noisy and dusty.Rooms needed little bit more care (by guests as well as by staff)
ginger is the best budget hotel in new delhi, in area near railway station. all facilities like taxi, food, shopping are available nearby.
jus the place outside hotel is to be maintained.. the stay at hotel was awesome with excellent room amenities.and that too economical.

we booked this as we were going to be catching a train from Corbett National Park into new Delhi station. but our driver had all sorts of problems trying to get to the front door and ended up parking in nearby car park! it's not in the nicest of areas, I definitely wouldn't advise walking around on your own at night.

it is clean enough, although they do not provide sheets apart from the one covering the mat. it has what you need, and it's clean and clean, despite the price for room it provides.it is the central location, the hotel is a great value for money. if you stay stay in this hotel, stay at this luxlux hotel in the heart of the stts - stay! i love the location and the nice price of room you can stay here here.

the resteraunt is open 24hours with good food although the staff are very rude and unanattentive. downside is that there are no shops around the hotel and you need to get to them (Connaught Place 5mins) which are available just outside a hotel.
the hotel is decent & as per Ginger standards. its located very conviniently esp if one wants to travel from NDLS station or arives these late at night.
my friends and I booked a room at Ginger to save some money. the room came highly recommended by my friend's coworkers in Bombay, but we ended up not staying there.
the room service was quick and the food was satisfactory. the rooms were neat & clean.I would recommend to the viewers to stay at this place.
hotel is clean & proper, has a good restaurant as well.Rooms are self sufficient, though small if you are looking at spending more than 3 days here.

ginger was just what we needed for the final 3 nights of our 3 1/2 week stay in India. the room was immaculate (by western standards rather than Indian) and complete with a fridge and tea and coffee making facilities, TV, comfy bed, AC, etc.

the restaurant / snack bar is good (try the plain dosa) it is a short trundle across the car park and through the little gateway from new Delhi railway station. the hotel has perimeter fence and security guard. Immediately outside, you're in an horrendous noisy tide of hand carts, jeeps and motorbikes etc.
